title: 112_hr953
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2011" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under Section 221 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2011" allows individuals to deduct qualified higher education expenses and interest on education loans paid during the taxable year. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition and fees for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The taxpayer can deduct qualified higher education expenses for an eligible student at an institution of higher education, including reasonable living expenses while attending. Expenses must be for courses that offer credit towards a degree. The eligible student must meet specific requirements to receive credit for courses towards a degree or certificate at an institution of higher education or vocational school. The term 'institution of higher education' is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. A 'qualified education loan' is a loan made, insured, or guaranteed by the Federal Government, a State, or a political subdivision of a State, or from the proceeds of a qualified student loan bond under section 144(b). The amount of interest on a qualified education loan for higher education expenses is limited. No double benefit is allowed for any expense under subsection (a). No deduction is allowed under subsection (a) for certain expenses if the taxpayer can claim a deduction under another provision. Additionally, no deduction is allowed if the taxpayer elects to apply a specific section for higher education expenses or if the individual is a dependent eligible for a deduction under a different section. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds any exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. The deduction is only allowed for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds any exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. It is only allowed for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year, with certain prepayments allowed for expenses in connection with an academic term beginning during the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next taxable year. Additionally, the amount of qualified higher education expenses is adjusted for certain scholarships and veterans benefits received by the individual for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to amounts exceeding exclusions under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. It applies to expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education, with prepayments allowed for expenses in connection with an academic term. The deduction does not apply to married individuals filing separate returns. The taxpayer and their spouse must file a joint return for the taxable year. Nonresident aliens can only apply this section if they are treated as resident aliens by election. The Secretary can create necessary regulations. A deduction for higher education expenses is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Section 221 of the tax code is amended by removing references to section 222 in various parts and sections. Additionally, section 62(a) is amended by renumbering paragraphs and other sections are also updated by removing references to section 222. The tax code is updated by replacing references to section 221(d)(1) with section 221(c)(1) and amending the table of sections accordingly. The tax code amendments regarding higher education expenses will be effective for payments made after December 31, 2010.
